Module 2: Conjugate Models and Exact Inference

Module 2: Conjugate Models and Exact Inference

This module develops the theory of conjugate priors, with a focus on exponential family models and exact posterior calculations. We treat conjugacy as a structural property of prior–likelihood pairs and derive posterior and predictive distributions, as well as marginal likelihoods and Bayes factors.

1. Exponential Family Models

Definition 2.1 (Canonical Exponential Family)

Let ((, , )) be a measure space. A family of densities ({p_: }) with respect to () is a (canonical) exponential family if there exist:

  • a measurable statistic (T: ^k),
  • a natural parameter space (^k),
  • a log-partition function (A: ),
  • a base density (h: [0,)),

such that [ p_(x) = h(x) { ^T(x) - A() }, , ; x . ]

We assume (A() < ) for () and that () is open.

Proposition 2.2 (Moments via Log-Partition Function)

Assume differentiability of (A). Then [ A() = , ^2 A() = (T(X)). ]

Proof idea: Differentiate the normalizing identity (p_(x),(dx) = 1) with respect to ().

2. Conjugate Priors in Exponential Families

Definition 2.3 (Conjugate Prior)

Let ({P_: }) be a parametric family of distributions on ((, )). A family of priors ({{}: H}) on ((, )) is conjugate for ({P}) if for any prior ({}) and observed data (x), the posterior ((x)) is again in the same family, i.e. equals ({‘}) for some updated hyperparameter (’).

Theorem 2.4 (General Conjugate Prior for Exponential Families)

Consider an exponential family (p_(x) = h(x){^T(x) - A()}). For hyperparameters (_0 ^k) and (_0 > 0), define a prior density on () with respect to some reference measure () by [ (_0, _0) { _0^- _0 A() }. ]

Let (X_1, , X_n) be conditionally i.i.d. given () from (p_). Then the posterior density is [ (x_{1:n}) { (0 + {i=1}^n T(x_i))^- (_0 + n) A() }, ] i.e. the same functional form with updated hyperparameters [ _n = 0 + {i=1}^n T(x_i), _n = _0 + n. ]

Proof: Compute the joint density of ((, x_{1:n})) up to normalizing constants: [ (0, 0) {i=1}^n p(x_i) { _0^- 0 A() + {i=1}^n (^T(x_i) - A()) }. ] Group terms in () and (A()) to obtain the posterior kernel.

Assumptions

  • () open and (A) finite on ().
  • Prior normalizing constant finite (posterior propriety requires further integrability conditions).
  • Identifiability of the parameter () from (P_) for interpretability of posterior updates.

3. Classical Conjugate Pairs

3.1 Beta–Binomial Model

  • Likelihood: (X p (n,p)), [ (X=x p) = px(1-p){n-x}, x=0,1,,n. ]
  • Prior: (p (, )), density [ (p) = p{}(1-p){}, <p<1. ]

Theorem 2.5 (Beta–Binomial Conjugacy). The posterior is [ p x (+ x, + n - x). ]

Proof: Combine likelihood and prior, collect exponents of (p) and (1-p), and read off the Beta kernel.

Posterior Predictive Distribution. For a new count (X_{} p (m,p)), the posterior predictive mass function is [ (X_{} = k x) = _0^1 pk(1-p){m-k} , (p +x, + n - x), dp. ] This integral evaluates to a Beta–Binomial distribution; compute explicitly using Beta function identities.

3.2 Gamma–Poisson Model

  • Likelihood: (X_i ()) i.i.d., ((X_i=k ) = e^{-} ^k / k!).
  • Prior: ((, )) (shape–rate), density [ () = ^{} e^{-}, >0. ]

Theorem 2.6 (Gamma–Poisson Conjugacy). If (X_1,,X_n ) i.i.d. Poisson, the posterior is [ x_{1:n} (+ _{i=1}^n x_i,; + n). ]

Posterior Predictive. For future count (X_{} ()), derive the Negative Binomial predictive distribution by integrating out ().

3.3 Normal–Normal Models

We treat two cases:

  1. Known variance (^2).
  2. Unknown variance with inverse-gamma prior.

Known Variance

  • Likelihood: (Y_i N(, ^2)) i.i.d.
  • Prior: (N(m_0, v_0)).

Theorem 2.7 (Normal–Normal Conjugacy, Known Variance). The posterior for () is [ y_{1:n} N(m_n, v_n), ] where [ v_n^{-1} = v_0^{-1} + , m_n = v_n ( v_0^{-1} m_0 + ). ]

Proof: Complete the square in the exponent of the joint density of () and (y_{1:n}).

4. Marginal Likelihood and Bayes Factors

Definition 2.8 (Marginal Likelihood)

Given prior () and likelihood (p(x )), the marginal likelihood (or evidence) is [ m(x) = _p(x ), (d). ]

This normalizing constant appears in Bayes’ theorem and is central to model comparison.

Definition 2.9 (Bayes Factor)

For two models (M_1, M_2) with priors (_1, 2) and marginal likelihoods (m_1(x), m_2(x)), the Bayes factor in favor of (M_1) over (M_2) is [ BF{12}(x) = . ]

Example 2.10 (Beta–Binomial Model Comparison)

Consider two Beta priors on the same Binomial likelihood, ((_1, _1)) and ((_2, _2)). Compute the Bayes factor between the corresponding models by integrating the Binomial likelihood under each prior, using Beta function identities.

5. Assumptions and Discussion

  • Proper priors and propriety of posteriors: Conjugate forms give closed-form kernels, but proper posteriors require integrability conditions on hyperparameters (e.g., (,>0) in Beta–Binomial).
  • Identifiability: Exponential family structure typically yields identifiability, but degenerate designs or constraints can break it.
  • Interpretability of hyperparameters: Conjugate priors often admit clear interpretations (e.g., Beta parameters as pseudo-counts), useful for elicitation and sensitivity analysis.

6. Problem Set 2 (Representative Problems)

  1. General Conjugacy in Exponential Families. Prove Theorem 2.4 in full detail, including the case of multiple observations and verifying all measurability conditions.

  2. Beta–Binomial Predictive Distribution. Derive the Beta–Binomial posterior predictive distribution explicitly and compute its mean and variance. Compare these to the plug-in predictive distribution using the posterior mean of (p).

  3. Gamma–Poisson Predictive and Overdispersion. Show that the Gamma–Poisson predictive distribution is Negative Binomial and analyze its overdispersion relative to a Poisson with parameter equal to the posterior mean of ().

  4. Normal–Normal with Unknown Variance. For the Normal model with unknown variance and conjugate Normal–Inverse-Gamma prior, derive the joint posterior of ((,^2)) and the marginal posterior of (). Identify the Student-t predictive distribution for future observations.

  5. Bayes Factors with Conjugate Priors. In a normal mean testing problem with known variance, compute analytically the Bayes factor for testing (H_0: ) vs (H_1: ) using a Normal prior under (H_1). Compare the resulting evidence measure to the classical z-test p-value.
